qas.question: What is one reasons Shakespeare is a good place to focus on textual criticism?

answers.text: the texts, as transmitted, contain a considerable amount of variation,

qas.question: Aside from Shakespeare, what is another book that is a major focus of textual criticism?
Name two of the oldest civilizations that textual criticism has focused on.
Why is there opposition to textual criticism of Jewish and Muslim religious books?
Over approximately what expanse of time can textual criticism be applied to written works?

answers.text: a period of about five millennia

plausible_answers.text: texts, as transmitted, contain a considerable amount of variation

qas.question: Why do critics hate focusing on Shakespeare?
When were the most recent documents in criticism?
It's too taboo to criticize the Torah, Qur'an, and what other religion?

context: In the English language, the works of Shakespeare have been a particularly fertile ground for textual criticism—both because <a0_0>the <b5_0>texts, as transmitted, contain a considerable amount of variation<b5_0/>,<a0_0/> and because the effort and expense of producing superior editions of his works have always been widely viewed as worthwhile. The principles of textual criticism, although originally developed and refined for works of antiquity, <b6_0>the <a1_0>Bible<b6_0/><a1_0/>, and Shakespeare, have been applied to many works, extending backwards from the present to the earliest known written documents, in <a2_0><b7_0>Mesopotamia and Egypt<b7_0/><a2_0/>—<a4_0>a period of about five millennia<a4_0/>. However, the application of textual criticism to non-religious works does not antedate the invention of printing. While <b8_0>Christianity<b8_0/> has been relatively receptive to textual criticism, application of it to the Jewish (Masoretic) Torah and the Qur'an <a3_0>is, to the devout, taboo.<a3_0/>[citation needed]
